S3.T1.table:
Desiderata (Group) Average popularity lift (Abdollahpouri et al., 2020) Gini index (Adomavicius and Kwon, 2011; Braun et al., 2023) Popularity rank correlation (Zhu et al., 2021) Herfindahl- Diversity (Adomavicius and Kwon, 2011) Log popularity difference (ours)
(1) well behaved ✗ ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓
(2) zero centered ✓ ✓ ✗ ✓ ✓
(3) anti symmetric ✗ ✓ ✗ ✓ ✓
(4) long tail sensitivity ✗ ✓ ✗ ✗ ✓
(5) monotonicity ✓ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✓
Aggregation hℎhitalic_h mean Gini coefficient identity sum of squares mean
Transformation g𝑔gitalic_g identity normalization by total popularity rank normalization by total popularity log
Comparison M𝑀Mitalic_M relative difference difference correlation difference difference
(Group) Average popularity lift (Abdollahpouri et al., 2020) Gini index (Adomavicius and Kwon, 2011; Braun et al., 2023) Popularity rank correlation (Zhu et al., 2021) Herfindahl- Diversity (Adomavicius and Kwon, 2011) Log popularity difference (ours) long tail sensitivity normalization by total popularity normalization by total popularity
references:
We review a subset of existing metrics commonly used in the literature and discuss them in light of the above desiderata. We selected metrics that are consistent with our previously stated base assumptions. In particular, they can all be formalized within the same framework for specific functions <math alttext="h" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S3.SS2.p1.1.m1.1">

italic_M, as shown in Table 1. While this list of metrics is by no means exhaustive, we think that the selected metrics are representative of the main ideas and assumptions underlying most existing metrics in the literature. Table 1 provides a condensed overview of the alignment between these metrics and our desiderata.

We review a subset of existing metrics commonly used in the literature and discuss them in light of the above desiderata. We selected metrics that are consistent with our previously stated base assumptions. In particular, they can all be formalized within the same framework for specific functions <math alttext="h" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S3.SS2.p1.1.m1.1">

While this list of metrics is by no means exhaustive, we think that the selected metrics are representative of the main ideas and assumptions underlying most existing metrics in the literature. Table 1 provides a condensed overview of the alignment between these metrics and our desiderata.

We compare the metrics from Table 1 with each other based on the popularity bias values that are reported in Table 2 ( 8 8 8 8 values, original model performance for each metric) and Table 8 8 8 8 8 8 8 8 88 88 8 values, original model performance for each metric) and Table 3 ( 8 8 8 8 additional values, model performance under two mitigation strategies for each metric). In total we base the correlation analysis on 8 8 8 8 8 8 8 8 88 88 8 additional values, model performance under two mitigation strategies for each metric). In total we base the correlation analysis on 8 + 8 = 16 8 8 16 8+8=16 8 + 8 = 16 popularity bias values for four different metrics, i.e., Gini–diversity, Herfindahl–diversity, average popularity lift, and our suggested metric, the log popularity difference. Unsurprisingly, log popularity difference and average popularity lift show a very strong correlation, as measured by Kendal’s 8 + 8 = 16 8 8 16 8+8=16 8 + 8 = 16 8 + 8 = 16 8 + 8 8 8+ +8 8= =16 16 8 8 16 8 8 16 8 8 8 88 816 168+8=16 8+8=168 + 8 = 16 8 + 8 = 16 popularity bias values for four different metrics, i.e., Gini–diversity, Herfindahl–diversity, average popularity lift, and our suggested metric, the log popularity difference.
